description:
Grammomys surdaster, commonly known as the woodland thicket rat, is a species of rodent in the family Muridae. It is found in parts of East Africa, including Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda.

The woodland thicket rat is a small, dark-colored rodent with a rounded body and a relatively short tail. It has a dense, soft fur coat that ranges in color from dark brown to reddish-brown. The species is characterized by its large, rounded ears and a distinctive white spot at the base of each ear.

Grammomys surdaster is primarily nocturnal and arboreal, living in dense thickets, bushes, and forests. It is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of plant materials, insects, and small invertebrates. The species is known to be a skilled climber and builds its nests in the branches of trees or shrubs.

The woodland thicket rat is considered a common and widespread species within its natural range. However, habitat loss and fragmentation due to human activities, such as deforestation and agricultural expansion, may pose a threat to its long-term survival in some areas.
